content.text: Welcome to a busy Dutch train station! Your goal is to find your platform. Remember the Dutch use the 'OV-chipkaart' for all public transport. You need to 'inchecken' (check in) before your journey and 'uitchecken' (check out) at your destination.

data.tip: The 'oo' sound is long, like in the English word 'spore'. The 'r' is a rolling 'r' sound, common in Dutch.

content.title: Getting Help Urgently
content.setting: You're at Utrecht Centraal during rush hour. Your train leaves soon, but you can't find the platform. You spot an NS employee and approach them.

conversation_flow.title: Say that you have a question.
Tell them you need the train to Rotterdam.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Oké, ik begrijp het. Even kijken...

content.text: Dutch numbers can be tricky in a noisy environment. Don't worry about asking someone to repeat themselves. It's very common!

content.title: Understanding the Directions
content.setting: The employee has found your train information on their device.

conversation_flow.title: You didn't quite catch the platform number. Ask them to repeat it slowly.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: De Intercity naar {destination} vertrekt van spoor zeventien.

conversation_flow.title: Listen carefully for the repeated number.

content.text: Repeating information back is a great way to confirm you've understood correctly, especially with important details like platform numbers. Using 'Dus...' (So...) is a natural way to start your confirmation.

content.title: Confirm and Go
content.setting: You've heard the number more clearly now. It's time to confirm and head to your train.

conversation_flow.title: Repeat the platform number back to confirm it's seventeen.
Thank the employee for their help.
